prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Opportunity to coordinate with other litigation

para.paratext: The opportunity to coordinate an action pending before the Panel with other litigation is an important factor favoring transfer. This factor is obviously relevant in all cases, since transfer of civil actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings is the most fundamental purpose of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407. This factor is therefore discussed, or the facts establishing it are virtually self-evident, in most Panel decisions.

This factor plays a very important role in selecting a transferee district.[1] It is also fundamentally related to the Panel's decision on whether transfer should be ordered. Transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 may be the only means of facilitating the efficient and expeditious handling of litigation and this factor may be quite important in the Panel's decision. This factor may be equally relevant with respect to actions that are not subject to transfer by the Panel but that present an opportunity to permit more efficient operation of the judiciary. For example, the Panel transferred a case for assignment to a judge who had presided over related litigation which had settled.[2] Transfer of the non-settled tag-along case permitted the most efficient handling of it despite the fact that the settled actions were no longer pending. The Panel has also noted that transfer of civil cases to a district where related (but not transferable) bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings were pending was appropriate in order to facilitate the best use of judicial resources.[3] The Panel has noted that transfer is especially useful in antitrust litigation because it permits coordination with federal civil and criminal antitrust cases not subject to transfer. The Panel has observed:

Tremendous success has been achieved in other multidistrict litigation, such as the Government Auto Fleet Litigation, through the cooperation of all the judges and the parties involved in coordinating discovery in the private treble damage actions with that in the Government criminal and civil actions. Because neither of the Government actions is subject to transfer under Section 1407, such coordination in this litigation can best be achieved by transferring all actions to the Eastern District of Michigan.[4]
Transfer has also been ordered to permit the federal court actions to be coordinated with those pending in the state courts.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The role of this factor as it relates to coordination with other cases pending in the federal courts is discussed in § 6:12. Coordination with state court proceedings is discussed in § 6:13.
See, e.g., In re Seeburg-Commonwealth United Merger Litigation, 362 F. Supp. 568, 571 (J.P.M.L. 1973), judgment aff'd, 518 F.2d 402 (2d Cir. 1975).
See, e.g., In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225, 230 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 221 (J.P.M.L. 1971).

See In re Toilet Seat Antitrust Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 1342, 1344 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (footnotes omitted). The reference is to In re Government Auto Fleet Sales, 328 F. Supp. 218 (J.P.M.L. 1971). The government cases are not subject to transfer because criminal cases are not within the purview of the statute in any event and government civil cases are expressly excluded from transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(g).

This reason for transfer is discussed in greater detail in § 6:13 as to selection of a transferee district. See also In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 261 F.
